title: el-nino-de-la-terminal
description: Miguel, a curious 8-year-old Latino boy, spends his days in the airport playground while his mother works as a janitor.

chapters.title: The Playroom
chapters.description: Miguel spends his days in the airport playground while his mother works as a janitor.

sentences.Mi mamá dice que es como un pueblo grand: My mom says it's like a big town, but I only know this terminal.
sentences.La sala de juegos, con sus toboganes azu: The playroom, with its blue and red slides and its labyrinth of tunnels, is my castle.
sentences.Llegan niños de todas partes, arrastrado: Children arrive from everywhere, pulled along by their dads who are gazing at the big bright panels.
sentences.Ríen, corren, construyen castillos con l: They laugh, run, build castles with the giant blocks.
They play for a while and then, poof!, they're gone.
sentences.Desaparecen por esas puertas enormes, co: They disappear through those enormous doors, with their small backpacks and their passports.
I, on the other hand, stay.
sentences.Mis pies conocen cada centímetro del sue: My feet know every inch of the cushioned floor.
I can see my mom in the distance.
sentences.Su uniforme gris y su carrito de limpiez: Her gray uniform and her cleaning cart are like a lighthouse to me.
sentences.El chirrido de sus ruedas es la banda so: The squeak of its wheels is the soundtrack of my day.
sentences.Ella se mueve despacio, siempre limpiand: She moves slowly, always cleaning, picking up what others leave behind.
sentences.Hoy, una señora con un bolso brillante y: Today, a lady with a shiny purse and dark glasses stopped her.
sentences.Le habló rápido, con los dedos señalando: She spoke to her quickly, her fingers pointing at the floor, her voice sharp and annoying.
sentences.Mamá, con su pañuelo en la cabeza, escuc: Mom, with her headscarf, listened in silence.
sentences.Su espalda estaba recta, pero pude verla: Her back was straight, but I could see her tense up a little.
sentences.No entendí todas las palabras, pero el t: I didn't understand all the words, but the lady's tone was like a blow.
sentences.Mamá le contestó bajito, una disculpa, c: Mom replied softly, an apology, I think.
sentences.Y la señora solo movió la cabeza con des: And the lady just shook her head disdainfully and kept walking, without looking back.
A lump formed in my throat.
sentences.¿Por qué le hablaban así a mi mamá?: Why were they talking to my mom like that?
sentences.Ella es fuerte, limpia todo, hace que el: She's strong, she cleans everything, she makes the airport look nice.
sentences.¿Por qué esa señora no la respetó?: Why didn't that lady respect her?
sentences.Mi mamá, ajena a mi furia silenciosa, so: My mom, oblivious to my silent fury, just kept cleaning, her mop making circles on the floor.
sentences.La miré, moviéndose entre la multitud qu: I watched her, moving among the crowd that came and went.
sentences.Y en el bullicio, sentí un orgullo extra: And in the bustle, I felt a strange pride for her, mixed with a confusion I didn't know where to put.

chapters.title: Echoes in the Terminal
chapters.description: Miguel observes the airport patterns and the temporary friendships he makes.

sentences.Ahora sé que el aeropuerto tiene su prop: Now I know the airport has its own heart.
It's no longer just noise; it's a heartbeat.
sentences.Las voces de los altavoces, que antes er: The voices from the loudspeakers, which used to be a confusing mix, are now like repeated songs.
sentences.\"Vuelo 741 a Los Ángeles, embarcando po: "Flight 741 to Los Angeles, boarding at gate 12." I hear that announcement about ten times a day.
sentences.Veo a las familias, cargadas de maletas: I see families, laden with suitcases and in a hurry, like a river that never stops.
sentences.A veces, algún niño se escapa un momento: Sometimes, a child will escape from their parents for a moment and make their way to the play area.
sentences.Un día jugué a los astronautas con una n: One day I played astronauts with a little girl who had a teddy bear.
sentences.Nos reímos mucho, inventando planetas y: We laughed a lot, inventing planets and spaceships.
But her laughter didn't last long.
sentences.Nuestro vuelo está listo.\" Y así, tan r: Our flight is ready." And just like that, as quickly as she arrived, she was gone.
The teddy bear, the laughter, everything.
I make friends for a little while.
sentences.Amigos que se suben a aviones y se van a: Friends who get on planes and go to places with beautiful names: Miami, Cancun, London.
sentences.Yo los veo desaparecer, y me quedo aquí,: I watch them disappear, and I stay here, in my personal "waiting room."
sentences.Mientras mi mamá limpia los baños o vací: While my mom cleans the bathrooms or empties the trash cans, I think about this.
sentences.¿Por qué mi vida no es como un vuelo con: Why isn't my life like a flight with a destination?
sentences.¿Por qué estoy siempre en la terminal, m: Why am I always in the terminal, while everyone else has a "takeoff" waiting?
The announcements are for them, not for me.
sentences.\"Última llamada para el vuelo 223 a Chi: "Last call for flight 223 to Chicago." And I, sitting alone on the colorful carpet of the play area, listen.
sentences.Me pregunto cuándo sonará mi propia llam: I wonder when my own call will sound, when it will be my turn to leave this waiting room too and start my own journey.
